Text: Tom Mboya, labour leader and nationalist politician, is first in contact with Robert Gabor, a Hungarian exile in the United States with ties to the CIA. Gabor runs the International Feature Service (IFS), an anti-communist wire service for newspapers across the globe. Mboya publishes two articles with the IFS, which were reproduced in 25 newspapers around the world.

International Feature Service becomes Peace with Freedom, a non-profit organization that apparently acted as a CIA front organization. Peace with Freedom made monthly donations to the Kenya Federation of Labour, the trade union umbrella body run by Mboya, until June 1964. With Heinz Putzrath of the Friedrich Ebert Foundation, Peace with Freedom funds the printing and publishing of the KFL’s newspaper, Mfanyi Kazi.
Entities: Tom Mboya; CIA; Kenya Federation of Labour; Heinz Putzrath; Mfanyi Kazi

Text: Gabor, Putzrath, George Githii, at this time a close ally of Mboya, and Tony Hughes, press secretary for KANU, agree to found the East African Institute of Social and Cultural Affairs. Githii was the inaugural general secretary. A governing board – including Bibi Titi Mohamed, Wilbert Chagula and Okot p’Btek – was formed but never meets.
Entities: Robert Gabor; Heinz Putzrath; George Githii; Tony Hughes; KANU; East African Institute of Social and Cultural Affairs; Bibi Titi Mohamed; Wilbert Chagula; Okot p’Btek

Text: Under Bethwell Ogot’s leadership – Githii resigned to take up a post as Jomo Kenyatta’s private secretary – the EAISCA opens for business with a series of seminars. Richard Garver, a CIA agent, is appointed to the EAISCA’s staff.
Entities: Bethwell Ogot; George Githii; Richard Garver; EAISCA

Text: The first issue of the East Africa Journal is published, initially edited by Odinge Odera. Odera is fired after a year following his criticism of the Kenyan government’s policy towards Southern Rhodesia. He is replaced by Ogot.
Entities: East Africa Journal; Odinge Odera; Bethwell Ogot

Text: The radical rival to the EAISCA, the Lumumba Institute, is opened in Nairobi. Closely tied to Oginga Odinga, it only remains open for a few months before being closed amidst coup rumours in April 1965
The East African Publishing House opens for business under the auspices of the EAISCA.

The East Africa Journal publishes what is – in 2023 – its most famous article; the critique written by Barack Obama Sr. of Tom Mboya’s development policy. Other landmark issues include the regular literary special editions, Ghala, edited by Philip Ochieng.
Entities: East Africa Journal; Tom Mboya; Ghala; Philip Ochieng

Text: In preparation for a presidential bid by Mboya, Gabor, Putzrath and other key allies of the Kenyan leader increase their funding for him.
Entities: Tom Mboya; Robert Gabor; Heinz Putzrath

Text: Gabor’s links to the CIA and support for Mboya and the EAISCA are debated in parliament. Mboya’s rivals from the left and the right are openly critical of his ties to Gabor.
Entities: Robert Gabor; CIA; Tom Mboya; EAISCA

Text: Vice President and Minister for Home Affairs Daniel Arap Moi warns Kenyan politicians from seeking external funding support from groups tied to foreign trade unions. Moi is Mboya’s biggest rival to succeed Jomo Kenyatta when the elderly first president dies. Mboya is the target of a failed assassination attempt.
Entities: Daniel Arap Moi; Tom Mboya; Jomo Kenyatta

Text: Moi declares Gabor, Putzrath and Garver to be prohibited immigrants. Funding for the EAISCA dries up almost immediately and is replaced in November 1968 by an ineffectual East African Cultural Trust.
Entities: Robert Gabor; Heinz Putzrath; Richard Garver; EAISCA

Text: Further revelations about Mboya, Gabor and the CIA are published in the American magazine Ramparts.
Entities: Robert Gabor; Tom Mboya; CIA; Ramparts

Text: Mboya is assassinated in Nairobi. The EAPH is taken over by the Ministry of Education almost immediately. Ogot remains involved in the EAPH but is finally ousted in 1974. The East Africa Journal continues to be published, but under much tighter financial constraints
Entities: Tom Mboya; EAPH; Bethwell Ogot; East Africa Journal

Text: The East Africa Journal stops being produced.
